Expectation1: Provide initial medical care to patients
Situation1: The ambulance driver is responding to a patient with symptoms of a major heart attack
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: The siren wailed as I sped through the city, my mind focused on the man in the back, clutching his chest, his face pale and slick with sweat. As the ambulance driver, I knew every second counted; I had to keep him stable, monitor his vitals, and radio updates to the hospital. My hands shook as I checked his pulse, trying to remember my training, trying to stay calm. But my phone buzzed on the dashboard—a reminder that my volunteer shift started in ten minutes. I was the only one with the keys to the community center, and people would already be lining up outside, waiting for warmth and food. I pictured their faces, the trust they placed in me to open the doors on time. The weight of both roles pressed down on me. I couldn’t be in two places at once, and both needed me now. My heart pounded as I wrestled with the impossible choice, torn between the life in my care and the community depending on me.
